segments.text: When Lucy was already very ill, Dr. Horowitz told Joseph that now, while she's in remission, they should make the most of the remaining time for pleasures, perhaps the last one she might have.
Take her on a trip to a nice place, maybe to meet friends she hasn't seen in a while and would be happy to see.
Ask her what she wants to do the most, and that's what you'll do.
This break won't last, and it's important to seize every moment.
Only then did Joseph realize that within a few months she would disappear from his life, from their lives.
No more than four, maybe less, of course, it's hard to know.
Until that moment, he suppressed all thoughts of it despite all the hospitalizations, treatments, and other reminders of her illness.
She lost a lot of weight and paradoxically to her physical state, suddenly appeared more slender.

Not that she was overweight before, but something more refined was noticeable in her lean silhouette, with her silver hair cut short due to treatments, therefore parting with her famous banana hairstyle, but still held back with two combs, revealing her beautiful face where now her cheekbones were accentuated.
He lit himself a cigarette, inhaled deeply, and slowly released the smoke.
With the smoke clouds enveloping him, memories from the first time he met her came back, at that premiere of the broom, theater where she worked as a costume designer.
He saw her standing in the corner, a young, beautiful woman with a sad look in her eyes.
Her gathered hair streaked with silver at such a young age, with a white stripe in the center, as if painted with a brush stroke.
Through weeks afterward, he begged her to let him paint her until she agreed, and as soon as he finished sketching her eyebrows, he knew he was completely in love.
Only later did he discover the mixture of her beauty with her wisdom, sharp intellect, and myriad talents.
But more than anything, she had that talent with people, to have deep conversations with them and especially to know how to listen.
as if all the tragedies she experienced in her life equipped her with the ability to contain the pain of others, and perhaps by doing so to quiet her own.
For all these reasons, he loved her immensely.
True, he wronged her more than once, but oddly it didn't diminish his love for her.
Somehow always realizing she loved him, he felt it was a lost cause.
You can't compete against a rival whose love was cruelly cut short at its peak just two weeks after their wedding.
A great love, as he often heard from her old friends.
On the night her husband, Abraham, was murdered by Arab attackers, that white stripe in her hair appeared.
That stripe gave her a mysterious look, completing the sadness reflecting from her eyes.
That white stripe captivated the eyes of his painter, who noticed every subtle detail and wouldn't rest until she allowed him to paint her.
As her portrait details were completed on his drawing block, he felt his heart reaching out to her.
He was captivated by her eyes and her warm, sad gaze.
And just as he finished drawing, still holding his simple pencil between his fingers, he was already in love.
I want to go to Tiberius.
She said when he asked her where she'd like to travel.
I want to see the Sea of Galilee again.
They say it's beautiful now.
Interesting, he thought, specifically Tiberius of all places.
He arranged for them with Nahum the driver.
The little one, as Lucy called her, was left alone at the hotel.
She's not little at all anymore.
She has crossed the age of 15 and was slowly becoming a young lady.
She is completely independent and knows how to manage on her own at the hotel.
And Fortuna will be there to help her.
She's very smart, Lucy told him shortly before.
She only took from us the good things and left those that are less with us.
She has Lucy's eyes with the deep gaze, but it's unclear how she got that special blue color from Lucy's gray eyes combined with his brown eyes with the spritz of green around the pupil.
as if she wanted to have a unique color of her own.
Without a doubt, her eyes are the first thing noticed when looking at her.
She absorbed a lot from them at home, the culture, the books and the music surrounding her.
And she was full of them, loving to read, play music and ride horses.
and loved the dogs she has been raising since childhood.
She is straightforward, unpretentious, but knows how to articulate fluently and has a beautiful language.
Like them she is immersed in books, even poetry books, and commands the English language from the time when the oil drillers from Texas stayed at their hotel for almost two years.
And even knows how to sprinkle some French words which she hears in Lucy's kitchen when she speaks French with Fortuna.
a free spirited, barefoot child.
His little girl, he loved her until there was nothing left of him.
Everything she did or said was good in his eyes.

Sometimes in a moment of truth, when looking at her from the side, he felt ashamed and guilty about the son he didn't raise, whom he distanced from his life due to his weakness and inability to handle his mother's outbursts, whom he separated from after a year of marriage, half leaving, half fleeing to the brigade.
His daughter knew nothing about it.
This is a subject that was never discussed, and Lucy respected his wish even though she disagreed.
One day he would have to tell her, but he delayed it.
He wasn't sure he could bear her gaze after the revelation.
It's nothing to be proud of having a child you abandoned before they turned five, and when they almost turned thirteen, you allowed their mother's new partner to adopt them.
After many years of not being in touch, he thought he had no right to insist, and it was only appropriate for someone else to take his place.
There was also an emotional blackmail element in her demand, promising to grant him a divorce after all those years since due to her insistence.
He never married Lucy, but now when it was already possible, it was Lucy who thought there was no point in it.
What good is it, she said, and it stayed that way.
He remembered it completely.

Sometimes he couldn't believe that such an unmatched and strange couple like them would produce such a sweet and beautiful child with his light hair and brown eyes and that smile of his that melted him every time he came to visit.

But that day, when he left never to return, leaving him with a puppy he brought him, it completely drove her out of her mind, and in a totally hysterical outburst, she raised a hand and almost slapped him.
He kissed his child swiftly and left, never to return.
The ride continued leisurely, with caution.
Nahem drove with extra care, worried Lucy might feel unwell.
He remembered the previous drives when he took her to the hospital in Tel Aviv for treatments and radiation.
Almost always on the way back, she would vomit her soul out.
A close bond was formed between them because of this.
He would hold her forehead and support her back until the anger passed and she would calm down, breathe deeply and drink from the water he offered her.
And only then would they continue their way.
Without this, he still owed her greatly, as one day she called him, knowing he was looking for work after his job at the oil drilling ended.
Their acquaintance stemmed from this.
Through the group of oil drillers from Texas that stayed at their pink house for almost two years.
Listen, she said to him then.

There are many vacationers here who want someone to take them for a drive here, a drive there, maybe to the park with a tour around the Ashkelon Antiquities, a short explanation about the history of the place.
Even tourists wanting a trip to Jerusalem, the Dead Sea or Tel Aviv.
There's no one more suitable than you.
I'll refer them to you.
So you have some livelihood with your car.
This fits you perfectly.
What do you say?
Thus his livelihood was created and he gained prosperity from her.
Twice he already replaced his vehicle for a newer one.
Other hotels heard about him and approached him.
And there were quite a few days when his schedule was completely full.
And to keep up with it, he employed another friend or two.
But always, when it was Lucy who called him, he dropped everything and stood by her side.

For him there was something elevated about her, something different as if she was the queen other, not out of arrogance, but something innate in her qualities, nobility and appearance which seemed to complete the picture.
Her gray eyes with the silver-gray gathered hair, a combination of determination and intelligence with sharp humor and a lot of human warmth.
And now he was driving her with Joseph, as they sat in the back, holding hands, looking at the beautiful scenery on both sides of the road.

He glanced at her through the mirror and fought to himself that she looked great, a bit too thin maybe, but her cheekbones suddenly appeared sculpted and a kind of joyful glow in her eyes, like a child taken on a school trip, beaming with delight.
He hoped dearly she passed the worst, but deep in his heart he didn't fool himself.

Something in the atmosphere around, in Lucy's clinging to each passing landscape picture, her impatience for the moment when the Sea of Galilee would be revealed, and in Joseph who never let go of her hand.
Aroused in him a sense of farewell party, on the descents towards the Sea of Galilee, with tall, thick and green trees rising on both sides of the road,
A clear memory passed over Lucy from the vacation at Cozumere.
The last time she saw her parents with her sister.
The year was 1937.
Both were young, cheerful and beautiful, happy each in her own part, happy with their parents.
Everyone's so delighted at the chance to be together suddenly.

After not seeing her for an entire year since she emigrated to Palestine, whenever she thought of her parents with longing, her heart broken over the suffering they endured until they perished in Treblinka, a spark of thought always arose in her that actually she had the opportunity to part from them during a magical vacation a few years earlier.
And that's what she would remember forever.
She knew the day was not far when she would be gathered to them, but there was no fear in her, only a quiet acceptance.
Sometimes in her dreams, she saw them welcoming her joyfully, hugging, caressing.
Apparently no person ceases to be their parents' little child, no matter how old they are.
Until the day they die, they will yearn for a mother's and father's embrace.
But she would leave her little one without that embrace.
She regretted that she wouldn't get to see her grow and become a woman.
She wasn't worried for her.
She knew this child was born with both feet on the ground, with wisdom and common sense.
I have a child with common sense, Joseph said almost from the day she was born, and he was right.
This is a fearless child, not of life and not of people.
And she would have to settle for Joseph's embraces, who loves her so much.
and there was also her older daughter from her first marriage, which quickly failed.
She is already a mother of two, and even if their relations seem warm, there was always a distance between her and this child, who grew up in a kabut since the age of twelve.
At least she got to embrace grandchildren, and she knows she did all she could to wrap her and assist her in everything.
Who knows?
Perhaps she could still watch from above as they all grow.
Oh, look, Joseph!
There's the Sea of Galilee!
She suddenly cried, clasping her hands.
The view that unfolded before them was delightful to the eyes.
And he couldn't remember when he last saw her so excited.
A cheerful, albeit slightly tired, smile spread across her lips, and her eyes shone with excitement.
She glanced at Joseph tenderly.
So many ups and downs they had experienced in their life together.
But she always knew there was great love for her in him.
accompanied by a kind of admiration.
And in recent months, from the moment it was clear her illness had returned, he treated her with nobility, care and gentleness, which helped her get through day by day.
She knew this was her last trip, but her heart was at peace.
